intro: Acalypha explorationis, commonly known as the red-hot poker or fireplant, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of Africa. It is characterized by its striking, tubular red bracts that resemble poker chips, giving it its common name. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers inside the bracts, which are often overlooked due to the vibrant color of the foliage. Acalypha explorationis typically grows as an upright shrub, reaching heights of up to 3 meters. It thrives in full sun and well-drained soil, making it a popular choice for ornamental gardening.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acalypha explorationis is primarily native to the Pacific Islands, including Hawaii, Tahiti, and other tropical regions of Oceania. It is an important part of the local ecosystem, providing habitat and food for various native species. Due to its ornamental value, it has also been introduced to other parts of the world.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acalypha explorationis was mainly introduced to New Zealand as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and adaptability to various soil conditions. It has since spread beyond cultivated areas and is now found in disturbed habitats such as roadsides, stream banks, and forest margins. The plant's rapid growth and ability to thrive in different environments have contributed to its establishment in natural ecosystems.
